questions.text: Chromatin contains which of the following components?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chromatin is the chromosomal material in the nuclei of cells of eukaryotic organisms.

  • Chromatin consists of,
    • Very long double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) molecules: The dsDNA helix in each chromosome has a length that is thousands of times the diameter of the cell nucleus. (Option A ruled out)
    • Small basic proteins termed histones: The histones help to condense the DNA, and also integrally participate in gene regulation. (Option B ruled out)
    • Smaller amount of nonhistone proteins (most of which are acidic and larger than histones): The nonhistone proteins include enzymes involved in DNA replication and repair, and the proteins involved in RNA synthesis, processing, and transport to the cytoplasm. (Option C ruled out)
    • Small quantity of (Option D)
    • Electron microscopic studies of chromatin have demonstrated dense spherical particles called nucleosomes, which are approximately 10 nm in diameter and connected by DNA filaments. Nucleosomes are composed of DNA wound around an octameric complex of histone molecules.

questions.text: Compared to nuclear DNA, mitochondrial DNA has,
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mitochondrial DNA has very few untranslated sequences compared to nuclear DNA.

Mitochondrial DNA

General Characteristics

  • Structure: Small, circular, double-stranded DNA (Option D)
  • Copies per cell: Each mitochondrion contains 2 to 10 copies
  • Size: Contains 16,569 base pairs (~16 kb)
  • Proportion: Makes up about 1% of total cellular DNA
  • Strands: Composed of a heavy (H) and light (L) strand

Genetic Content

  • Encodes 13 polypeptides of the respiratory chain, including:
    • 7 subunits of NADH dehydrogenase (Complex I)
    • Cytochrome b (Complex III)
    • 3 subunits of cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV)
    • 2 subunits of ATP synthase
  • Also encodes:
    • 2 rRNAs: 12S (small) and 16S (large)
    • 22 tRNAs
  • Note: The majority of mitochondrial proteins (~54 of 67) are encoded by nuclear genes

Unique Genetic Code

  • Genetic code differs slightly from nuclear DNA: (Option C)
    • UGA → Tryptophan (Trp), not a stop codon in mitochondrial DNA
    • AGA and AGG → Stop codons, not Arginine

Special Features

  • Contains very few untranslated (non-coding) sequences
  • High mutation rate: 5 to 10 times higher than nuclear DNA
  • mtDNA sequence comparisons are used in evolutionary studies

Inheritance Pattern

  • Inherited maternally (non-Mendelian inheritance)
  • All mitochondria are contributed by the ovum
  • Affected mothers can pass mtDNA mutations to all children
  • Only daughters can transmit the trait
  • Some mtDNA deletions may occur during oogenesis and are not inherited

Associated Diseases

  • Mutations in mtDNA are linked to:
    • Myopathies
    • Neurologic disorders
    • Some forms of diabetes mellitus

General Characteristics

  • Structure: Small, circular, double-stranded DNA
  • Copies per cell: Each mitochondrion contains 2 to 10 copies
  • Size: Contains 16,569 base pairs (~16 kb)
  • Proportion: Makes up about 1% of total cellular DNA
  • Strands: Composed of a heavy (H) and light (L) strand

Genetic Content

  • Encodes 13 polypeptides of the respiratory chain, including:
    • 7 subunits of NADH dehydrogenase (Complex I)
    • Cytochrome b (Complex III)
    • 3 subunits of cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV)
    • 2 subunits of ATP synthase
  • Also encodes:
    • 2 rRNAs: 12S (small) and 16S (large)
    • 22 tRNAs
  • Note: The majority of mitochondrial proteins (~54 of 67) are encoded by nuclear genes

Unique Genetic Code

  • Genetic code differs from nuclear DNA:
    • UGA → Tryptophan (Trp), not a stop codon
    • AGA and AGG → Stop codons, not Arginine

Special Features

  • Contains very few untranslated (non-coding) sequences
  • High mutation rate: 5 to 10 times higher than nuclear DNA (Option B)
  • mtDNA sequence comparisons are used in evolutionary studies

Inheritance Pattern

  • Inherited maternally (non-Mendelian inheritance)
  • All mitochondria are contributed by the ovum
  • Affected mothers can pass mtDNA mutations to all children
  • Only daughters can transmit the trait
  • Some mtDNA deletions may occur during oogenesis and are not inherited

Associated Diseases

  • Mutations in mtDNA are linked to:
    • Myopathies
    • Neurologic disorders
    • Some forms of diabetes mellitus

(Option B) High mutation rate compare to nuclear DNA (5-10 times that of nuclear DNA)

(Option C) Genetic code of mitochondrial DNA slightly differs from the standard code

UGA (standard stop codon) is read as Trp (Tryptophan)

AGA and AGG (standard codons for Arg - Arginine) are read as stop codons

(Option D) Mitochondrial DNA is circular, double stranded DNA (nuclear DNA is linear and double stranded)

questions.text: Which of the following types of histone covalent modification is associated with DNA repair?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The four core histones are subject to at least six types of covalent modification or posttranslational modifications (PTMs): Acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, ADP-ribosylation, monoubiquitylation, and sumoylation.
  • These histone modifications play important roles in chromatin structure and function, as given in the following table:

Methylation (Option A) of histones is correlated with activation and repression of gene transcription.

Sumoylation (Option C) of histones is associated with transcription repression

Acetylation (Option D) is associated with chromosomal assembly during DNA replication

choices.text: Short DNA consisting of roughly only 30 bp

questions.text: Which of the following is a true sentence about linker DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In chromatin, core nucleosome particles are connected by DNA, termed "linker DNA".

  • It is a short DNA consisting of roughly 30-bp regions. (Option A)
  • It links two nucleosomes and is not present inside the nucleosome core. (Option B)
  • Contains the histone H1, whereas the H2A & H2B histones are present in the nucleosome core. (Option C)
  • Two strands of DNA are linked by hydrogen bonds, not linker DNA. (Option D)

choices.text: Nucleosome structure of active chromatin remain the same
More sensitive to digestion by a nuclease

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding chromatin containing active genes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Some regions of chromatin are active & others are inactive.

  • Generally, every cell of an individual metazoan organism contains the same genetic information. Thus, the differences between cell types within an organism must be explained by differential expression of the common genetic information.
  • Chromatin containing active genes (ie, transcriptionally or potentially transcriptionally active chromatin) has been shown to differ in several ways from that of inactive regions:
    • The nucleosome structure of active chromatin appears to be altered, sometimes quite extensively, in highly active regions. (Option A)
    • DNA in active chromatin contains large regions (about 100,000 bases long) that are relatively more sensitive to digestion by a nuclease such as DNase I.
    • Transcriptionally inactive chromatin is densely packed during interphase, as observed by electron microscopic studies and is referred to as heterochromatin (Option D). In contrast, transcriptionally active chromatin stains less densely and is referred to as euchromatin. (Option C)
  • Generally, euchromatin is replicated earlier than heterochromatin in the mammalian cell cycle.
  • The chromatin in these regions of inactivity is often high in meC content, and histones therein contain relatively lower levels of certain activating covalent modifications and higher levels of repressing histone post-translational modifications.

choices.text: Found in the regions near the chromosomal centromere and telomeres
When it is actively transcribed, then it is uncondensed and appears as euchromatin

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of facultative heterochromatin?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • There are two types of heterochromatin:
    • Constitutive:
      • It is always condensed and thus essentially inactive. (Option A & B)
      • It is found in the regions near the chromosomal centromere and at chromosomal ends (telomeres). (Option C)
    • Facultative:
      • Facultative heterochromatin is at times condensed, but at other times it is actively transcribed and, thus, uncondensed and appears as euchromatin.
  • Of the two members of the X chromosome pair in mammalian females, one X chromosome is almost completely inactive transcriptionally and is heterochromatic.
  • However, the heterochromatic X chromosome condenses during gametogenesis and becomes transcriptionally active during early embryogenesis - thus, it is facultative heterochromatin.

questions.text: Chromosomal DNA is packaged and organised at several levels. The highest packing ratio is found in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Higher-order structures provide for the compaction of chromatin.

questions.text: What is true about telomeres?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Telomeres consist of short TG-rich repeats.

  • Human telomeres have a variable number of repeats of the sequence 5'-TTAGGG-3', which can extend for several kilobases.
  • The ends of each chromosome contain structures called telomeres.
  • The centromere connects two sister chromatids. (Option B)
  • Telomerase, a multisubunit RNA template-containing complex related to viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerases (reverse transcriptases), is the enzyme responsible for telomere synthesis and thus for maintaining the length of the telomere. (Option C)
  • Telomere shortening has been associated with both malignant transformation and ageing (Option D), so telomeres and telomerase enzymes have become an attractive target for cancer chemotherapy and drug development.

choices.text: Coding regions are often interrupted by intervening sequences
Coding regions are termed as introns, and noncoding regions are termed as exons
Coding regions are much longer than non-coding regions
Coding regions may help in genetic rearrangement by recombination

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding coding and noncoding regions in DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In eukaryotic DNA, coding regions, which ultimately appear in the cytoplasm as single mRNA molecules, are often interrupted by large non-protein-coding sequences.

  • These intervening sequences, or introns, are present in the primary mRNA transcript (originally called hnRNA).
  • Before the mRNA becomes mature, these introns must be precisely removed, and the coding segments, called exons, are spliced together. (Option B)
  • Most genes have at least one intron and can have as many as 50.
  • In many cases, the introns are longer than the exons. (Option C)
  • Although the exact role of introns isn't completely clear, they allow for alternative splicing, which increases the variety of proteins produced from a single gene.
  • They may also allow for more rapid recombination and genetic rearrangement by separating functional domains of coding information. (Option D)
  • Occasionally, other RNA molecules may also be located within intronic DNA.

questions.text: The Alu family in the human genome is present in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • At least 30% of the human genome consists of repetitive DNA sequences.
  • One type of repetitive DNA is the SINEs (Short Interspersed Nuclear Elements).
  • The Alu family belongs to the SINEs and is highly abundant in the human genome.
  • The Alu sequences are present in about 500,000 copies per haploid genome and make up approximately 10% of the human genome.
  • Another category of repetitive sequences includes microsatellite repeats, consisting of 2 to 6 base pair units repeated in tandem (e.g., AC, CG, AT, CA), commonly found 50,000 to 100,000 times in the genome. (Option C)
  • Some trinucleotide repeats (like CGG, CAG, CTG) can expand and cause genetic diseases such as fragile X syndrome and Huntington's disease. (Option D)
  • LINE-1 (Long Interspersed Nuclear Element-1) is a type of autonomous retrotransposon that inserts copies of itself into the genome using an RNA intermediate. Its activity is usually strongly suppressed in somatic cells to maintain genome stability and prevent DNA damage. (Option A)

choices.text: Occurs during the M phase of the cell cycle

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of DNA replication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Salient Features of DNA Replication

  • DNA replication is the process of copying DNA to pass genetic information from the parent cell to daughter cells.
  • It occurs during the S phase of the cell cycle, also known as the Synthetic phase. (Option D)
  • Two new complementary strands are synthesised from a double-stranded DNA (dsDNA)
  • One strand goes to each daughter nucleus; hence, in each daughter cell, one strand is from the parent, and one is newly synthesised.
  • This mechanism is called semiconservative synthesis, as the parental DNA strand is conserved in the daughter cells. (Option A)
  • Replication requires a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) template, which is generated after unwinding dsDNA.
  • On one DNA strand, synthesis is continuous; on the other strand, it is discontinuous. (Option C)
  • After replication, the parental and newly synthesised strands re-form a dsDNA.
  • Replication begins at specific sites of initiation, where a replication complex assembles.
  • The process ensures genetic stability by being complete and involving proofreading mechanisms for high fidelity.
  • Synthesis of new DNA requires four dNTPs, enzymes, and magnesium.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes leads to the unwinding of DNA during DNA replication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Helicases lead to the unwinding of DNA during replication.

DNA polymerase (Option A) leads to deoxynucleotide polymerisation.

Topoisomerase (Option B) relieves torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding

DNA Primase (Option D) initiates synthesis of RNA primers.

questions.text: A replication fork consists of all of the following components except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A replication fork consists of four components that form in the following sequence:

  1. DNA helicase unwinds a short segment of the parental duplex DNA
  2. SSBs bind to ssDNA and prevent premature reannealing of ssDNA to dsDNA
  3. Primase initiates the synthesis of an RNA molecule that is essential for priming DNA synthesis
  4. DNA polymerase initiates the synthesis of the nascent daughter strand

DNA ligase (Option D) is involved in sealing the single-strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand at termination of replication.

questions.text: Okazaki fragments are found on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • DNA polymerases only synthesise DNA in the 5' to 3' direction. Because the DNA strands are antiparallel, the polymerase functions asymmetrically.
  • On the leading (forward) strand, the DNA is synthesised continuously.
  • On the lagging (retrograde) strand, the DNA is synthesised in short (1-5 kb) fragments, the so-called Okazaki fragments, so named after the scientist who discovered them.
  • Several Okazaki fragments (up to 1000) must be sequentially synthesised for each replication fork.

On the leading (forward) strand (Option B), the DNA is synthesised continuously and hence does not form Okazaki fragments.

Messenger RNA and Ribosomal RNA (Option C & D): Any RNA does not contain Okazaki fragments.

questions.text: Primosome is a mobile complex between:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During DNA replication, several Okazaki fragments (up to 1000) must be synthesised on the lagging strand at each replication fork.
  • To initiate this, helicase unwinds double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) in the 5′ to 3′ direction.
  • Helicase associates with primase to give primase proper access to the DNA template.
  • This interaction enables RNA primer synthesis, which is essential because DNA polymerases cannot initiate DNA synthesis de novo.
  • The mobile complex formed between helicase and primase is called the primosome.
  • Once an Okazaki fragment is completed and the polymerase is released, a new RNA primer is synthesised for the next fragment.
  • The same DNA polymerase remains at the replication fork to synthesise the next Okazaki fragment.

questions.text: A number of different DNA polymerase molecules engage in DNA replication. All of them share the following properties, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Multiple DNA polymerases are involved in DNA replication.
  • These polymerases share three key properties:
    • Chain elongation (Option A) - Refers to the rate of nucleotide addition (measured in nucleotides per second).
    • Processivity (Option B) - Refers to the number of nucleotides added before the polymerase dissociates from the template strand.
    • Proofreading (Option C) - Involves detecting and correcting errors in nucleotide incorporation.
  • Chain termination (Option D) is not a shared property of DNA polymerases and is not part of the replication function. DNA ligase, not DNA polymerase, seals nicks between Okazaki fragments at the end of replication on the lagging strand.
  • In coli:
    • DNA polymerase III (pol III):
      • Works at the replication fork.
      • Has the highest rate of chain elongation and maximum processivity.
      • Can polymerize up to 0.5 Mb in one cycle on the leading strand.
      • Associates with β subunits of the sliding clamp, enhancing its stability, processivity (100-50,000 nt), and elongation rate (20-50 nt/s).
    • DNA polymerase I (pol I) and II (pol II):
      • Primarily involved in proofreading and repair.
  • Eukaryotes have equivalents of these polymerases and many additional ones, mostly used in DNA repair.

choices.text: RNA polymerase having reverse transcriptase activity

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding reverse transcriptase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Reverse transcriptase is an enzyme that functions as an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase. It synthesises DNA using RNA as a template.
  • RNA polymerase lacks reverse transcriptase activity and performs only transcription. In contrast, telomerase enzymes do possess reverse transcriptase activity. (Option A ruled out)
  • It should not be confused with DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which synthesises RNA from a DNA template. (Option B ruled out)
    Reverse transcriptase is present in RNA viruses, specifically retroviruses.
  • In retroviruses, this enzyme synthesises a single-stranded DNA (and then a double-stranded DNA) from the single-stranded RNA genome. This process begins with the formation of a DNA-RNA hybrid molecule. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Progress through the mammalian cell cycle is continuously monitored via multiple cell-cycle checkpoints. Which of the following cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) regulates the transition of the cell cycle from G2 to M phase?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CDK1 is involved in the transition from G2 to M phase.

General Role of Cyclins and CDKs

  • Cyclins are proteins whose levels rise and fall throughout the cell cycle.
  • They regulate cell cycle progression by activating cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs).
  • CDKs are serine/threonine protein kinases that phosphorylate key substrates at specific cell cycle stages.

G1 Phase and G1/S Transition

  • Cyclin D levels increase in the late G1 phase.
  • Cyclin D activates CDK4 and CDK6, forming active cyclin D-CDK4/6 complexes. (Option C & D)
  • These complexes phosphorylate the retinoblastoma (Rb) protein.
  • Unphosphorylated Rb binds and inactivates E2F, a transcription factor needed for S-phase gene expression.
  • Phosphorylation of Rb releases E2F, leading to transcription of genes required for DNA synthesis.
  • This transition past the restriction point commits the cell irreversibly to enter the S phase.

S Phase Initiation

  • Cyclin E-CDK2 complex forms in late G1 and helps initiate S phase. (Option B)
  • After cyclin E is degraded, CDK2 pairs with cyclin A to continue and support DNA replication.

G2/M Transition

  • Cyclin B-CDK1 complex is essential for the transition from the G2 phase into mitosis (M phase).
  • This complex acts as the rate-limiting factor for initiating mitosis.

Cancer and Cell Cycle Dysregulation

  • Oncoviruses and oncogenes can bypass normal G1 to S phase controls.
  • Overproduction of cyclins, loss of CDK inhibitors, or premature activation of CDK-cyclin complexes may lead to uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • Some viral oncoproteins inactivate Rb, releasing E2F inappropriately and triggering abnormal cell division.
  • Inactivation or mutation of Rb, a tumor suppressor gene, is linked to cancer development.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy, born to consanguineous parents, presents with recurrent diarrhea, chest infections, fever, irritability, and weight loss. Labs show low hemoglobin and low WBC count. A probable diagnosis of SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency) was made. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Repair of damaged DNA is critical for maintaining genomic integrity and thereby preventing the propagation of mutations, either horizontally (somatic cells) or vertically (germ cells).
  • DNA is subjected to a huge array of chemical, physical, and biological assaults daily; hence, efficient recognition and repair of DNA lesions are essential.
  • Consequently, eukaryotic cells contain five major DNA repair pathways.
  • The mechanisms of DNA repair include nucleotide excision repair (NER), mismatch repair (MMR), base excision repair (BER), homologous recombination (HR), and nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ) repair pathways

There are many diseases associated with defective DNA repair mechanisms:

questions.text: UV light might damage DNA by forming pyrimidine dimers. Formation of pyrimidine dimers will be repaired by which of the following DNA repair mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

DNA is subjected to a huge array of chemical, physical, and biological assaults daily; hence, efficient recognition and repair of DNA lesions is essential.

  • Consequently, eukaryotic cells contain five major DNA repair pathways.
  • The mechanisms of DNA repair include
    • Nucleotide excision repair (NER)
    • Mismatch repair (MMR)
    • Base excision repair (BER)
    • Homologous recombination (HR)
    • Nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ)

choices.text: The sequences of nucleotides are opposite to the noncoding strand
The sequences of nucleotides match the sequence of mRNA transcripts
It is copied or transcribed during RNA synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the template strand of DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Within a particular gene in the double-stranded DNA molecules, the genetic information resides in the sequence of nucleotides on one strand, the template strand. It is sometimes referred to as the noncoding strand.
  • The opposite strand of the template strand is considered the coding strand because it matches the sequence of the RNA transcript (but containing uracil in place of thymine) that encodes the protein.
  • The relationship between the sequences of an RNA transcript and its gene, in which the coding and template strands are shown with their polarities in the above figure.
  • The RNA transcript with a 5' to 3' polarity is complementary to the template strand with its 3' to 5' polarity.
  • The sequence in the RNA transcript and its polarity are the same as that in the coding strand, except that the U of the transcript replaces the T of the gene; the initiating nucleotide of RNAs contains a terminal 5-triphosphate (pppA in the above image).

The sequences of nucleotides match the sequence of mRNA transcripts (Option A): The template strand is also known as a noncoding strand, so the sequences of nucleotides in the template strand are the same as the noncoding strand.

The sequences of nucleotides match the sequence of mRNA transcripts (Option B): The template strand sequences of nucleotides are complementary to the coding strands. The sequences of coding strand matches with the sequence of mRNA transcripts

It codes for proteins (Option C): The coding strand codes for proteins.

choices.text: Negative supercoils occur when B-DNA is twisted in the clockwise direction
Supercoiled DNA is a preferred form in biological systems

questions.text: The topoisomerase enzyme is an important target for chemotherapy. This enzyme can relax or insert supercoils in DNA. Which of the following is true about the supercoiling of DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Supercoils are introduced when a closed circle is twisted around its own axis or when a linear piece of duplex DNA, whose ends are fixed, is twisted.
  • This energy-requiring process puts the molecule under torsional stress, and the greater the number of supercoils, the greater the stress or torsion.
  • Topoisomerase is an enzyme that catalyzes topological changes of DNA.
  • Topoisomerase enzymes can relax or insert supercoils in DNA, using ATP as an energy source.
  • Supercoiling is a prerequisite for DNA replication and transcription, so topoisomerase is an important target for chemotherapy.

Topoisomerases present in humans only (Option A): Homologs of this enzyme exist in all organisms, not only in humans.

Negative supercoils occur when B-DNA is twisted in the clockwise direction (Option B): Negative supercoils are formed when the molecule is twisted in the direction opposite from the clockwise turns of the right-handed double helix found in B-DNA. Such DNA is said to be underwound.

Circular DNA cannot form supercoiling (Option D): Closed circles exist in relaxed or supercoiled forms.
